content.text: Letters from Father Christmas  Once upon a time, in a cozy little house at the edge of a snowy village, there lived three children named Mary, John, and their younger brother, Peter.
Every year, as Christmas drew near, the children would leave out a mince pie and a glass of milk for Father Christmas, just as their mother had taught them.
And every year, without fail, they would wake to find the treats gone—and in their place, a letter from Father Christmas himself.
But these were no ordinary letters.
They were written in shaky, spidery handwriting, as if an old man with cold fingers had penned them by the light of a flickering candle.
The envelopes were always dusted with snow, and sometimes, a tiny smudge of soot from the chimney would mark the paper.
The children treasured these letters more than any toy, for they told the most wonderful stories of life at the North Pole.
Dear Mary, John, and Peter,  I hope this letter finds you well.
It has been a very busy year at the North Pole!
The reindeer have been practicing their flying, and I must say, Prancer has become quite the show-off—he keeps doing loop-the-loops in the sky, which makes the elves giggle.
Poor Donner, though, still hasn’t quite mastered landing without tripping over his own hooves.
The workshop has been humming with activity.
We’ve been making toys for children all over the world, and I must admit, the dolls’ house your mother ordered for Mary is one of the finest we’ve ever built.
The elves painted tiny roses on the wallpaper, and the furniture is so small it would fit in the palm of your hand!
Now, I must tell you about a little mishap we had last week.
The Polar Bear—you remember him, the great white fellow who helps me with heavy lifting—decided to try his paw at baking.
He wanted to make gingerbread men for the elves, but he got a bit carried away.
He used all the flour in the pantry, and when he opened the oven, the gingerbread men came to life and started running around the kitchen!
It took us hours to catch them all.
The Polar Bear was very cross with himself, but the elves thought it was the funniest thing they’d ever seen.
Do be good, and remember to leave out a carrot for the reindeer. They love carrots.
With much love, Father Christmas  P.S. Peter, I hear you’ve been practicing your handwriting. Very impressive! Keep it up.
My Dear Children,  Another year has flown by, and what a year it has been!
The reindeer have been training hard, and I’m pleased to say that Donner has finally learned to land properly.
(Though he did crash into the sleigh shed last week—luckily, no one was hurt, except for his pride.)  The workshop has been busier than ever.
The elves have been working day and night to finish all the toys, and I must say, they’ve outdone themselves.
John, the wooden train set you asked for is ready, and it even has a little whistle that goes toot-toot!

The elves tested it in the workshop, and it was so loud that the Polar Bear woke up from his nap and grumbled about “noisy little toys.”  Speaking of the Polar Bear, he has been up to his old tricks again.
Last month, he decided to go ice fishing.
He dug a hole in the frozen lake near the North Pole and sat there for hours, waiting for a fish to bite.
But the ice was thinner than he thought, and—SPLASH!—he fell right in!
The elves had to pull him out with a rope, and he was very grumpy about it.
He’s been sulking ever since, though I did see him sneaking extra honey from the pantry yesterday.
Mary, I hear you’ve been helping your mother with the baking. That’s wonderful!
Perhaps next year, you can help the elves decorate the gingerbread houses.
They always need an extra pair of hands. With love and sleigh bells, Father Christmas  P.S.
Peter, I’ve enclosed a tiny silver bell from my sleigh. Shake it gently—it’s magic!
Dearest Mary, John, and Peter,  Christmas is nearly here, and the North Pole is covered in a thick blanket of snow.
The reindeer have been practicing their flying formations, and I must say, they’re getting better every year.
Vixen has even learned to do a little dance in the air—she twirls her tail like a ballerina!
The workshop has been a hive of activity.
The elves have been working so hard that I’ve had to remind them to take breaks.
John, the toy soldiers you asked for are ready, and they’re dressed in the finest red coats.
The elves painted each one by hand, and they even made tiny swords that really shine.
Now, I must tell you about the Great Snowball Fight of 1922.
It all started when the Polar Bear decided to build a snowman outside the workshop.
He rolled three huge snowballs and stacked them up, but then he got a little too excited.
He started throwing snowballs at the elves, and before we knew it, everyone was joining in!
Even the reindeer got involved—they used their noses to toss snowballs at the Polar Bear. It was chaos!
The workshop was covered in snow, and the elves were laughing so hard they could barely stand.
The Polar Bear, of course, declared himself the winner, but I think the elves might have let him win.
Mary, I hear you’ve been reading lots of books. That’s wonderful!
Perhaps one day, you can write a story for the elves. They love a good tale.
With warmest wishes, Father Christmas  P.S.
Peter, the silver bell I sent last year—have you been taking good care of it?
Magic bells don’t like to be lost!
My Dear Children,  Another Christmas is upon us, and the North Pole is as busy as ever.
The reindeer have been practicing their flying in the snowstorms, and I must say, they’re getting very good at navigating through the wind.
Dasher has even learned to fly backward—though I’m not sure why he’d want to do that!
The workshop has been working overtime. The elves have been making dolls, trains, and all sorts of wonderful toys.
John, the model ship you asked for is ready, and it even has tiny sails that really catch the wind.
The elves tested it in the bathtub (don’t tell the Polar Bear—he thinks baths are for “sissies”).
Now, I must tell you about the Polar Bear’s latest adventure.
Last week, he decided to go exploring near the Ice Caves.
He packed a picnic (mostly honey sandwiches) and set off, but he took a wrong turn and ended up in the Cave of the Northern Lights.
The lights were so bright that they danced on the walls, and the Polar Bear was mesmerized.
He sat there for hours, watching them, until he fell asleep.
The elves had to go looking for him, and when they found him, he was snoring so loudly that the ice walls shook!
Mary, I hear you’ve been helping your mother with the Christmas decorations. That’s lovely!
The elves always say that a house decorated with love is the most beautiful of all.
With love and starlight, Father Christmas  P.S. Peter, have you been practicing your numbers?
The elves need help counting all the toys!
My Dearest Mary, John, and Peter,  This will be my last letter to you for a while, my dear children.
You’re growing up so fast, and soon, you’ll be too old to believe in the magic of Christmas.
But I want you to know that the North Pole will always be here, and the magic will always be real—for those who believe.
The reindeer have been practicing their flying one last time, and they’re ready for the long journey ahead.
The workshop is quiet now, with all the toys packed and ready to go.
The elves have gone to bed early, tired but happy after another year of hard work.
The Polar Bear is snoring by the fire, dreaming of honey and snowball fights.
He’ll wake up tomorrow, grumpy as ever, but with a heart full of love for the children who believe in him.
Mary, John, and Peter, you have brought so much joy to the North Pole.
Your letters, your kindness, and your belief in the magic of Christmas have made every year brighter.
Never stop believing, even when others tell you it’s just a story.
The magic is real, and it lives in your hearts.
With all my love, now and always, Father Christmas  P.S.
Peter, don’t forget to leave out a carrot for the reindeer. They’ll miss you.
And so, the children grew up, but they never forgot the letters from Father Christmas.
They kept them in a special box, and every Christmas Eve, they would take them out and read them by the fire.
And though they no longer left out mince pies and milk, they still believed—in the magic, in the wonder, and in the love that Father Christmas had brought into their lives.
For that is the greatest gift of all.
